qas.question: What is the main function of direction lanterns?

answers.text: to help people decide whether or not to get on the elevator

qas.question: What might change your mind about whether or not to enter an elevator?

answers.text: If somebody waiting for the elevator wants to go up, but a car comes first that indicates that it is going down

qas.question: What type of etching might you see on a direction indicator?
Some elevators may use the color convention for only what purpose?

context: Direction lanterns are also found both inside and outside elevator cars, but they should always be visible from outside because their primary purpose is <a0_0>to help people decide whether or not to get on the elevator<a0_0/>. <a1_0>If somebody waiting for the elevator wants to go up, but a car comes first that indicates that it is going down<a1_0/>, then the person may decide not to get on the elevator. If the person waits, then one will still stop going up. Direction indicators are sometimes etched with <a2_0>arrows or shaped like arrows<a2_0/> and/or use the convention that one that lights up red means "down" and green means "up". Since the color convention is often undermined or overridden by systems that do not invoke it, it is usually used only in conjunction with other differentiating factors. An example of a place whose elevators use only the color convention <a3_0>to differentiate between directions<a3_0/> is the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago, where a single circle can be made to light up green for "up" and red for "down". Sometimes directions must be inferred by the position of the indicators relative to one another.
